text: Family Member: And the scale - is that improving or not or - Patient: Thirty-eight point six or thirty-eight. Family Member: I don’t know Doctor: It was forty-eight in July. Patient: Right. Doctor: And when I saw him on November seventh he had been on the pills for two weeks. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And then so that could be one of the first things that drops the PSA and then we expect with that shot that you received that it’s going to drop it even further. And so that’s what we’re looking for today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so we’re really with our fingers crossed that you know your cancer is shrinking and diving because of what we’ve done, and uh that the issue with that big amount of cancer that is around how your urine gets out of your body—that also will improve, and then we could think about getting your catheter out. Patient: Uh hum. That sounds good. Doctor: This is a copy for us.

text: Family Member 1: Yes, super hormones uh for what duration? Doctor: We, uh I give them for three months for four doses of chemo three weeks apart. Family Member 1: And let me ask you um, Are there any treatments that you use with the PSMA that targeted those cells, um? Doctor: Um yes, so, so, you’re talking about like PSMA radionuclide therapy and um right now there are a couple of clinical trials in the United States for guys who have failed hormone therapy. There are also – um you can do that – I’ve sent probably; uh I’ve sent twelve guys over to Germany to get that therapy in the last eighteen months uh you know specifically to try and like avoid like hormone therapy or something. What I can tell you is in this setting that therapy is not curing anybody. So if you’d asked me eighteen months ago, I would have said sure, let’s send you over there. What I’ve learned in the last eighteen months is that nobody I’ve sent over has been cured by that therapy, and uh I don’t consider it worthwhile right now. Family Member 1: Okay, and then the other question was - I don’t know if this makes a difference or not, Do we have a Gleason score of the margins that were left? Doctor: So it’s and uh irrelevant and undoable because you know the therapy he received, uh we wouldn’t uh it’s not scored. Family Member 1: I see. Doctor: So it’s, But it’s irrelevant. The cancer’s out. It’s an aggressive cancer. Family Member 1: Um Hmm. Patient: What are the side effects from the chemo and super hormones? Doctor: Yeah, uh so the biggest side effect, quite frankly, so let’s talk about hormones first. Uh because the super hormones don’t add anything. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: And that’s, and the data is clear. Everything else we’re doing you have to do is you know unmeasurable. Family Member: Um hum. text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: My approach would be as we discussed last time to wait until that PSA level goes above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if we don’t. Doctor: If it continues at the same pace you know if it increases by one or two decimal points, who knows, it may take you know six to nine months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Maybe up to twelve months. Doctor: But things that are nausea medicines require prescriptions.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
